monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: It is said that once upon a time, there were two brothers. One of them was well-off, blessed by God with wealth and prosperity, while the other had nothing.

It is said that one of the brothers had a large number of sheep, so many that when he took them out to graze, they would block the sunlight. His brother, on the other hand, worked as a shepherd for him because he was poor and owned nothing.

It is said that when he went out, he found a man dressed in a white robe. The man approached the ewe, the one that was glowing, and carried it so it could eat. The ewe tried to escape, but he kept bringing it back.

So the brother went to him and said: "What are you looking for, sir? Who are you? Why are you among my brother's sheep?" The man replied, "I am your brother's fortune." The brother said, "Oh! You are my brother's fortune? I wonder, where is my fortune?"
He replied, "You too, go and search for your fortune. Your fortune is in a valley, the Valley of Fortune. Go, search for it, and find it!"
Anyways, it is said he thought, "I wonder if I..." He left his brother's wealth and set out on the path. It is said that while he was on the road, walking along, he suddenly saw a wolf.
The wolf had lost all its fur; there wasn’t a single hair left on its body. The wolf asked him, "Where are you going?" You see, back in the old days, it is said that animals used to talk.

He replied, "Actually, I’m heading to the Valley of Fortune, searching for my luck (Saʕd-i). I want to ask about it because my luck seems dead." The wolf said, "I beg you, sir! If you find your luck, ask about mine too! Look at me—I’ve lost all my fur and don’t know why!"

"Could you keep me in mind?" the wolf pleaded. "I, too, have been searching for answers. Please, ask on my behalf! Look at me—I’m hairless, a bald wolf! The other wolves mock me because I have no fur."
"Won’t you ask on my behalf when my fur will grow back?" the wolf asked. The man replied, "Alright! I will ask for both myself and you!"
It is said that he continued walking, and as he walked, he reached a place. And there, he saw what? He saw a woman.
It means that initially, he was a man, a ruler of that entire place, let's say the leader of that place.
And it is said that he stayed there for the night. And when he stayed there, he came to him again and said:
He asked him, "Where are you going, I wonder?"
He said, "In truth, I am searching for it. Do you know where it is? I want to go to the Valley of Fortune to ask about my luck."

He said, "My luck has died, and I want to ask about it." The other person replied, "Listen, I will tell you something, but keep it between us. Do not expose me." He said, "Go ahead, tell me!" The man said, "If you find the Valley of Fortune and ask about your luck,..."
"Can you ask on my behalf why I haven't been able to get married until now? Why hasn't my luck helped me yet?" He replied, "Alright, I'll ask on your behalf as well."
It is said that he kept walking, and along the way, he would ask people, and they would direct him, saying, "It’s in such-and-such a place," and he would continue on his journey.
It is said that he reached that lake, and in the lake, there was a snake. It was this wide, lying still in the water.
It is said that he went beside it, as animals in ancient times had the ability to speak.
She asked him, "Where are you going?" He replied, "Do you not know of the Valley of Fortune? I am searching for it."
She said, "Ah! Since you are going there, could you not ask for me as well? I cannot dive into the water. I fload over the water."
She said, "I will carry you across the canal, but on the condition that you ask for me as well—why I cannot dive."
He said, "Alright, carry me, and if I remember, I will ask for you as well." It is said that he rode the snake, which carried him across the lake, and he continued his journey.
It is said that when he arrived at the Valley of Happiness, he looked around and asked, "Where is my luck?" They replied, "That is your luck!" pointing to a donkey resting in the mud.
It is said that he became angry, took a stick, and began hitting the donkey to awaken his luck.
It is said that he beat the donkey severely, and when the donkey woke up, it said, "Go! Now that I am awake!"

It is said that the donkey then spoke, saying, "If you knew how to eat, you would have known and found your luck! Here I am, I have risen. I am your luck. In case you didn't know, see that I have awakened!"

It is said that the man then returned, for he had awakened his luck. He went back to the snake, as he had asked his friends about her. He said, "In truth, when I was on the way, a snake carried me across the lake."

It is said that the man then spoke to the snake, saying: "Tell the snake to release a jewel from its mouth. This way, the jewel can go, and the snake will be able to dive into the water. This is the snake's task."

It is said that the man continued, "When I was on my journey, there was a ruler of that land, like the highest governor, the leader. He too asked me, 'Why doesn’t my luck rise? Why can’t I get married?'"
He said: "This is because he is a woman, not a man. He should find a man for himself and get married."
Ha! And this is also alright. Then he asked him about the hairless wolf. He said: "The hairless wolf?"
He said: "When I was on the way, there was a hairless wolf, and he asked me how he could grow his fur."
He said: "Let him eat the heart of someone who doesn't know what's good for him, and then his fur will grow."
The man said: "Alright!" and then returned to the snake, saying: "I have been told that I have awakened my fortune."
The man said, "I have awakened my fortune. Help me cross the water." She helped him across the water and then said, "You cannot dive because there is a jewel in your mouth."
She was told to throw the jewel in order to dive into the water. It is said that when she threw it, the jewel was this big.

Isn't this his luck? Take it! He didn't take it! Can you dive now? He said: No! I have awakened my luck, I don't need your jewel. She said: Fine, go to hell. She took her jewel back. She said: I will dive into the water. I can't dive. It doesn't matter to me.
She returned the jewel to her mouth. And he went back to that ruler, the ruler of that place, who was wealthy.
He said: "Oh man, did you ask about my fortune?" He replied: "Yes, I asked about your luck. You are not a man, you are a woman, you need to get married."
He said: "Do not expose me, my brother! Listen, I am rich, and all these places, houses, and lands are mine. I am the ruler of this land."
"Marry me, so that my secret is not exposed."
He said, "I will take you? What do I have to do with you? I have awakened my own luck."
He said, "Am I supposed to take you? Look at how I've become. You are rich, and it doesn't matter to me." And he didn't take her either.
He approached the hairless wolf. When he came to the wolf, he said: "So where are you going, what have you done?"
He asked: "Did you inquire about me? Did you awaken my fortune? What have you done?" He replied: "Let me tell you."
He said: "I went and did this and that, and this is what happened to me." He told him the story from the beginning to the end.
He said: "Did you ask on my behalf as well?" He replied, "Yes, I asked on your behalf. You need to eat the heart of the person who doesn't know their own good, and then your hair will grow."
He said: "There is no one better than you, who doesn't know," and he turned on him, ate his heart, and his hair grew back. Ha ha ha!
If you knew what was good for you after all that happened along the way—how the snake gave you the jewel and the man gave you wealth.
The woman gave you wealth, and you didn’t accept it? You, oh my God!
He ate his heart, and his hair grew back. This is the fate of someone who doesn't know their own good.
